text: Darkness. Then the GLINT of a flashlight. Its beam rocks  crazily to and fro across the inside of a small storage r as we hear two children arguing.
You're doing it wrong.
Shut up.
You're doing it wrong.

It's hard, but we get a sense of the room in the whipping beam of light. Huge, dark coats lined up like sides of be on steel batons. Bent, stained helmets hung like African  masks. Beneath them BRIAN, 7, and STEPHEN, 12, are trying to str into a pair of the ludicrously massive coats over their  pajamas.
It doesn't go like that.
Who asked you?
If you do it like that it'll open in  the fire. Then you'll get burned and
The door suddenly opens, morning sunlight roaring in. It' fire station storage room full of fire gear. A fireman st in the doorway, tall, athletic, their father; DENNIS  McCAFFREY.
Who's going to die?
Brian. He's not doing it right, dad.  He never does it right.
(gestures for them to  come out) Well, let's have a look.

The two boys tromp out of the closet. The rubber turn-out boots are as high as their thighs. The ends of the coats  drag on the floor. They salute, Brian's arm just an empty sleeve. Dennis kneels down and re-fastens Brian's coat.
Your brother's right. If you don't  fasten these correctly they could  open and you'd get burned.
And DIE!
You wouldn't let me die, would you,  Dad?
McCaffreys are smarter than fire,  Brian. (playfully slaps their  shoulders) How 'bout lunch, huh?
Fireman shit?
Hey, what's with the mouth? Where'd  you grow up, a barn?
Firehouse.
Cute.
-- The station suddenly fills with the BELLOW of an ALARM KLAXON.
(sighs) Never fails...
A young fireman, ADCOX, appears with the dispatch card.
Big deal?
Medium deal.
Want to come along, Brian? Watch the  old man earn his keep?
(pissed) Dad!
You've come along a dozen times,  Stephen, give your brother a chance.  We'll be back in a few minutes. (to Brian) How 'bout it, sport?
Sure!
Dennis scoops Brian up and loads him into the fire engine cab. The other three firemen climb aboard and take their  places.
There's a cough of diesel, a crunch of gears, and the eng is pulling out of the station.
Hit the button, Brian.

Brian stamps his foot on the siren button. The red light  snaps on, the siren growls and blares, and they're off do the street. Brian turns around in his seat and, at the la instant before the corner, makes eye contact with his old brother. They stick their tongues out.

The engine howls its way through the city. Brian, sandwic between his father and Adcox, looks out in wonderment at  intersections zipping past like picket fences, at people sidewalks holding hands over their ears, at the red emerg lights bouncing crazily off shop windows.

Lazy smoke curls out the second story of a commercial blo Medium deal. The engine pulls up and the firemen are jump off like ship rats. Dennis opens his door, hops down, and pauses just long enough to point a serious finger at his  son.
Stay near the truck. (winks) And keep an eye out for us, huh?  We're short handed today.
Brian nods vigorously, taking the command seriously. Denn smiles and is off, dragging a hoseline with his crew towa a doorway they disappear into. Brian climbs down from the cab.
Don't stray too far, little man.
Brian smiles to the pumper operator. He just wants a bett look. And he gets it: Smoke turned evil and dark now, tak on purpose.

There's a level of apartments above the storefronts. As B watches, a window opens and out steps his father and Adco onto a small fire escape. Their attention's on the next w over, out of reach, wrapped in leaky smoke. Suddenly Dennis climbs up onto the fire escape railing, a with only an axe, and JUMPS across to the next metal balc A ballsy, dangerous move. He kicks in the window, breaks the frame with his axe, and dives in. A beat later he reemerges on the balcony with a terrified smudged little girl. He hands the little girl over the ra to a fireman now coming up the more traditional way -- a  ladder. Dennis's face lifts and grins at Brian; dirty, bigger tha life, invincible. He winks a wink only possible between  fathers and sons and he's gone again, back into the swirl darkness. As Brian stands there, full of love, full of pr he sees a piece of awning along the roofline crack; relea a sickly yellow tongue of flame that slinks over the roof The flame seems to pause, to stare at Brian a beat. Shhh, don't tell anyone. Brian is transfixed, his little head  staring up in astonishment. Nobody else has noticed it. Brian can see his father and Adcox through the window;  probing, looking for the flame lurking just above. Brian  starts to call out in a small, hesitant voice,
Dad...

He tries to call louder... But suddenly everything is  happening very fast in slow motion: -- Brian can see Adcox testing the ceiling with a pike po as Brian steps forward, under the power of a flame that  beckons him as --  Dennis suddenly THROWS his body against Adcox, knocking h clear just as a flame EXPLODES DOWNWARD from the ceiling  fully against him as -- All the building's windows BLOW O and it's like the sky's erupted for Brian, a burning hail that falls and pelts the ground around him. Plaster, wood and something metal that cracks against the pavement and  spins slowly. A fire helmet. And Adcox is coming out the door now, blackened and torn, hopeless tears streaming down his face.
Get us some backup! We need some  goddamn backup!

And, spotting Brian, he runs towards him. And the helmet  spins and spins and Adcox keeps running, and the sky is  raining fire, and the flame on the roof has risen up now its full, horrifying size and it's laughing now, laughing the little boy as the helmet finally stops spinning, and read the printing on the neck guard.

And Adcox is sobbing and has his arms around the boy,  protecting him from the fire, the world, but it's like Br doesn't see him. He pulls away from Adcox, walks up to hi father's helmet, And puts it on. The scene EXPLODES with a flash as a photographer capture the instant.
Sequence omitted from original script.

Hold on the freeze-frame. Let it become an aged cover of  LIFE. The magazine jiggles and rocks and we see now it's  sitting atop a box of knick-knacks jostling in the back s of an aging BMW. There's plenty of other boxes here, a li on the move, and in the driver's seat, BRIAN McCAFFREY, n 27. There's piles of empty burger wrappers, Coke cans, an Florida knick-knacks on the dash board; a little blow-up  palm tree, a cheesy hula girl emblazoned with "McCaffrey  High-End Stereo Sales".
Brian and his battered BMW shoot past prairie, cow countr nervous suburbs and finally a sign: WELCOME TO CHICAGO.
Wind tugging at his bangs, Brian stares down at the grave of Dennis and Mary Elizabeth McCaffrey.
In a crusty sink he combs his hair, knots a tie around hi neck.
Brian walks through its sculpted columns, straightening h tie. He comes to a door, FIRE ACADEMY CHIEF. He takes a d breath, steadies his gaze, and enters.
The ACADEMY CHIEF sits at his desk going over a file. Out the window can be heard a FIRE TRAINING CLASS in action.
Is this a joke?
Brian's sitting in the seat opposite.
If it was a joke, sir, you'd be  laughing.
You walked out on this academy six  years ago. One week to graduation.  You think we forgot that? You think  I did?
I want another shot, Sir.
(beat) Look, everybody remembers your old  man. Being his son, all you had to  do was breathe to graduate here.  Dead Hero Father Rule. But you blew  us off. Why should I take you back?
If you remember, sir, my test scores  were in the top --
-- I don't give a damn what your  test scores were, maybe you could  have been a good firemen, but you  had your shot.
I need another one, sir.
Sorry, but it's out of my hands. Try  again next year.
No, it isn't out of your hands or  you wouldn't even have met me. If I  push you have to let me back in.  Dead Hero Father Rule. Sir.
(simmers) Even if you graduate this academy,  you've still got nine months of  probation. That's hard duty, son. If  you don't really love this job, it'll  kill you.
(rises) See you Monday. Sir.
As we hear the BLOW OF A WHISTLE
And everybody lined up at attention in dress blues.

(at podium) Though the world changes every day,  some things are truly forever:  Courage, devotion, and honor in what  we do. This class is a special one,  for we dedicate it to the three  firefighters that have fallen this  year: Donald Knowlton, Richard Walter  and Michael Petzold... (silent beat) Ladies and gentlemen, it is with  pleasure that I certify that Candidate  Class number 322, having successfully  completed all academy requirements,  are hereby graduated to the Chicago  Fire Department.

Candidates and their relatives CHEER and leap to their fe Something struggles inside of Brian. He doesn't stand at  first. Another Candidate, TIM, 20, looks at him strangely So does the Academy Chief, his eyes finding Brian's. And  Brian's standing slowly now, joining them...
An expensive one. We hear a window BREAK.
Through the dimness a file cabinet. An AXE SUDDENLY SLAMS into it, RIPPING it apart. Files crash to the floor. And picture. 1970. Four young guys marlin fishing. Time of th lives.
And a GREY PUTTY being SLAPPED along the edges of a door.

A split-level firemen's dive; complete with mounted axes personalized T-shirts from various engine companies proud declaring "LADDER CO. 6 -- AXE FIRST, HOSE LATER" and "CH FD, 150 YEARS OF TRADITION UNIMPEDED BY PROGRESS". Tonight the place is firmly in the hands of an army of  recently graduated candidates. A few on the back patio ha hooked up a charged hoseline and are taking potshots at  balloon targets, each other, the neighbor's cat. Brian an Tim, still in their uniforms, enter from the street. Surv the scene.
Completely out of control.
What the hell are we waiting for?
As they shoulder their way inside, another CANDIDATE appe holding proudly a fistful of sealed envelopes.
Hot off the presses, guys. Station  assignments.
Tim and everyone else but Brian eagerly tear into them. B nonchalantly shoulders up to the bar.
A beer, Willy!
The barkeep turns and smiles.

Well, if it isn't the littlest  McCaffrey. (to candidates with  hose) Hey! You break anything with that  you buy it! (to Brian) Sorry, there must be something wrong  with my eyes. I keep thinking that's  a fire department uniform.
It's in my blood, Willy.

The candidates are ripping open their assignments, exclai to each other: "All right! Engine 117! That's a slum! The get cookers every day!". "Oh no, Engine 10, that's a nice neighborhood"... Willy turns to the bulletin board behind him and unpins a stack of business cards.

Really. Well, let's have a look at  what else was "in your blood". I  always look forward to getting these,  they make such a nice collage for  the bar... "Assistant Director, Sales,  Aspen Snowmobile Tours..."
Didn't offer the kinda growth and  challenge I need.
Uh huh. And "Pioneer's Pride, Mobile  Log Cabins". That was in your blood  about six months wasn't it?
Management were pin heads.
"Laguna Jamming, Custom Surfboards"?
Coffee sucked.
And just this year, "Brian's Sound  Spectrum". Your own company even.  Big step.
I was ahead of my time.
You know, I've got a perfect little  spot here for "Brian McCaffrey,  Fireman"...
Tim holds an envelope marked McCAFFREY out to Brian.
Aren't you even curious?
Engine 115, right?
(opens it, surprised) How'd you know? These are supposed  to be sealed.
Lucky guess. (winks) And a case of scotch to a captain in  station assignments.
You crooked son of a bitch. Why 115?
Lots of fires. They promote faster  there. Take a look at the last Lt.'s  list, half the guys on it came from  that battalion. Gotta think about  your future, Timmy. 115's the station.
Ah man, if you're gonna bribe your  way into a station, why not 17 with  me and your brother?
On Brian's reaction

A Porsche knifes through darkened streets. The DRIVER, 50 is dressed for success. Pulling up to the brownstone we s earlier, he gets out and rubs his eyes. Another day in th salt mines. Climbing the short stairs, he sticks his key into the loc and opens the door. It is the last thing he will ever do. A THUNDERING EXPLOSION ENGULFS the stoop.
The place is packed now with girls flirting with the  candidates, putting their helmets on, etc. The horseplay  around the bar suddenly stops at the sweet sound of a SIR
Everyone steps outside, cocks an ear. And here it comes, real thing, SCREECHING past in a full-tilt rush. Shouts a raised toasts.
Hey, that's my cousin's company!  C'mon! Let's go!
As Brian turns, he suddenly confronted by an elderly  LITHUANIAN WOMAN.
(surprised) Mrs. Viatkus...
She grabs his cheeks and rattles off in Lithuanian. Brian can only smile. Then two attractive jean-clad legs step u JENNIFER.
Brian.
(surprised) Jennifer.
You're back.
You look great.
Thanks for calling.
Uh... I've been sorta keeping a low  profile... the academy... I graduated  today.
Huh.
So... I see you're still in the  neighborhood.
Not quite. Just visiting. I live in  Lincoln Park now.
Yeah? What have you been up to?
I work for city hall.
Really? No kidding.
What, you think I just dried up and  blew away when you left? The world  does turn once in awhile Brian, even  without your permission.
Just then, Tim OPENS UP the hoseline, DRENCHING Brian.
Don't want you overheating, Brian!
Brian ducks the stream and PULLS a length of hose near hi feet, FLIPPING Tim. Brian JUMPS him, shuts off the hose a pins him to the pavement.
Okay okay! Uncle!
Brian walks back toward Jennifer
You've certainly matured.
She turns to leave.
Well, if nothing else, it's nice to  know we can still be friends.
I don't want to be your friend, Brian.
Another in a series of fire engines HOWL past. Tim grabs  Brian by the shoulder.
Let's go, man!

Brian and Tim jump into Brian's car. They shoot blindly d the street looking for the fire engine, running down red  lights or anything else that gets in their way. Brian sud hits the brakes, SCREECHING to a stop. They roll down the windows. Far off can be heard the wind-up of a siren.
(points) That way.

SCREECH. They fly around a corner, down a block, and ther it is, lights flashing up ahead. Brian GUNS it, roars up  alongside the fire engine. Tim leans out the window, shak a bottle of beer, and lets loose a foamy eruption in the  truck driver's face.
Tim! You crazy motherfucker!
But he's laughing.
What'cha got?
Box alarm. Walton Ave.
We'll meet ya.

As Brian and Tim pull up two engine companies are already dragging lines toward the rolling brownstone we saw explo earlier. Tim cheers the firemen on like a drive-in movie. Brian watches the fire with uneasy fascination. Embers  whipping into the night, drifting to the ground around hi One of the engine companies is entering the doorway now. watches as they willingly crawl into a place any sane per would run for their life from. Jesus Christ. FLASH -- Bri turns at the blinding snap of a camera. Several locals ar gathered around a parked car, some taking pictures. Brian notices that right away. It takes a beat longer to notice the CHARRED CORPSE stuffed head-first through the windshi It's the Porsche driver, his legs sticking out at crazy  angles. A dog barks furiously at it.
(also looking at body) Man. Something sure put a crimp in  his evening.
Backdraft.

The brownstone fire quickly transforms itself into noisy  clouds of dirty white steam. And one of the firemen is co back out now, walking toward Brian. When he's just a few yards away he pulls off his air mask and helmet and we shudder with Brian, because the man is dead ringer for HIS FATHER.
Well, look what we have here. Nice  costume. Rent it?
I want to thank you for coming to my  graduation, Stephen. It was a great  inspiration to me.
So you're going to fight fires now,  huh?
He pats Brian's cheeks, leaving behind large charcoal sme
(re smears) Doesn't work on you. (turns to leave) See ya around, little brother.
Not likely.

(turns) Well, see you're wrong already. Had  a talk with Chief Fitzgerald, and we  decided in the interest of brotherly  love, that maybe you shouldn't be  way over on the other side of town.  So starting tomorrow, your assigned  to company 17. My company. (Brian's color drops  a hue) One case of scotch, you're getting  cheap in your old age, Brian...
And Stephen turns for his own men, Tim staring at Brian a clouds of smoke drift past like ghosts.

A flame LEAPS up into the foreground. Touches a cigarette The cigarette glows, lingers, then lowers slowly from the mouth of RIMGALE, fifty-five years old and six and a half feet of solid granite. Wearing a windbreaker and grey sla tucked into fire department rubber boots, he takes anothe slow drag. Looks at the body stuffed into the windshield. It's twenty yards away from the brownstone. Stephen looks as Rimgale drops the cigarette, crushes it with his boot, and crosses the street to the building.
Charred walls hiss and snap in the steamy darkness. Rimga is there, gloomy in the beam of his flashlight. He crouch down, plays his flashlight along the ruined baseboard.
If you stare any longer Stevie, I'll  start charging you admission.
Stephen is leaning in the doorway, watching him.
Got a cause?
Are the glory boys actually showing  interest in Investigation's work? I  may have a stroke.
The glory boys just want to finish  their report so they can go home.
Rimgale's flashlight finds a wall socket that he pries lo and holds up to the light. He lowers it, takes in the wal the room.
They're gonna have to wait a few  days on this one.

Tim's talking to his cousin. Brian hangs back, watches th body-bag people load the Porsche driver into a meat wagon There's a still an audience for this, still stray dogs  circling and barking. Brian walks up, looks inside the ca and sees on a seat the ragged remains of a FINGER.
(to coroner crew) Hey, you forgot... this.
They're already climbing into the wagon. The driver smile creepily.
We always leave something for the  dogs.
Brian looks across the fireground, sees his brother walki back to the fire engine. They share a brief, edgy glance.
A modest one. South-side Irish old fashioned. Brian walks up. There's a little kid, about five, playing with a toy  fire truck on the drive.
Hey, Sean. What's goin' on, man?
The kid stares at him without a glimmer of recognition.
It's Uncle Brian. Y'know.
He makes his hand into a talking puppet.
(bandito accent) "Spinach? We don't need no stinking  spinach". Remember?
The kid drops his toy truck and flees inside.
Mom! Mom!
Brian follows, sticks his head in the door.
Hellooo...
A warm looking woman, 30's, HELEN, comes around the corne
Brian?
Hi, Helen. Man, you look great.
You look like... Brian.
She gives him a tentative hug.
'Bout written you off. How long have  you been in town?
Four months.
Four months?
I know, I know, Should'a called.  I've been really busy. I joined the  fire department.
Helen's expression suddenly saddens.
Oh Brian... (beat) You guys... you really know how to  put each other through it, don't  you?
The little kid is peeking fearfully from the kitchen door
That's Sean? Jeez, he's a giant.
Yeah, you'd be surprised what three  years can do to a kid.
Sean, come on out, man. What, you  forget your favorite uncle?
Stephen told him you were killed in  a hot tub accident.
(intense) Dad was kidding, Mom.
And the kid runs unexpectedly away, angry.
Well that's two things to strangle  Stephen for. Where is he, anyway?
(beat) Stephen's not staying here now, Brian.  He moved out last April.
An embarrassed sting.
Oh, man, I'm sorry.
You guys ought to try picking up a  phone once in awhile.

A small one on the river. Several boats bob peacefully. E one. Raised high in dry-dock, it's an ancient fishing tra Bachman-Turner-Overdrive drifts up from the galley on bad fuzzed speakers as Brian climbs the ladder.
Hey.
Stripped to the waist, Stephen's bent-over cleaning out t guts of the inboard motor. He looks confused to see Brian
I talked to Helen...
Wrong thing to say. Stephen turns back to his work.
...Man, I thought dad's boat was  finally retired to the family  graveyard. Don't you worry about  falling out of this thing?
Stephen straightens up, his forearms smudged with grease. Brian admires the unwashed cereal bowls and peeling deck  paint.
I like what you've done with the  place.
It's comin' along... want a beer?
Stephen tosses him a beer from the fridge. As Brian pops he sees the small pile of city-issue gallon size cans in corner. Armorall, solvent, extinguisher foam.
Been ripping off fire stations?
It's old stuff Adcox gave me that  the department was going to throw  out anyway. Still good enough though  for this tub.
Brian winces at the music coming out of shot speakers.
Bachman Turner Overdrive? (looks through music  rack) ...Buffalo Springfield?... Stephen  Bishop? Oh man...
Brian lifts one of the tapes -- an 8-track -- and holds i carefully in his palm as if it were a rare and fragile re
My God, an actual operating 8-track.
What, you've never seen one before?
In the Field Museum once.
It works.
It worked when you were in sixth  grade.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Brian opens the trunk of his old BMW. It's full of stereo boxes marked BRIAN'S "SOUND SPECTRUM".
Brian's gutted the speakers and is re-wiring them.
People actually used to pay you for  this?
Millions, Stephen -- And sexual  favors.
Sheep don't count.
Yeah? What about Laura --
That was never proved.
Brian moves over to another speaker.
Why'd you come here, Brian?
I wanted to know why you messed with  my station assignment. I mean, is  this really gonna have to one of  those big brother -- little brother  "you broke my GI Joe and I'm still  pissed" games?

(sighs) What is it with you, man, huh? How  do you manage to keep coming up with  new and amazing ways to screw up?  That scotch bullshit? Am I really  supposed to believe you came crawling  back home because you suddenly felt  heart strings moan for the family  biz? You were bankrupt, man.
Hey! You don't know me --

I know you cold, Brian. The scary  thing is, you probably could have  faked it for awhile. But you see, in  this job there's no place to hide.  Isn't like selling log cabins. You  have a bad day here -- someone dies.  And that's not fucking good enough.  Want another beer?
So that's it? Big bad brother's gonna  ride my ass till I cough blood?
Big bad brother is going to treat  you like any other probie -- that I  don't think is going to make it.
Brian staples the last of the audio cord in place and swi on the tape player. The cabin fills with sharp, crystal c Stephen Bishop.
There's only so much technology can  do. (picks up his tool  box) Thanks for the beer.
Thanks for the speakers.
Brian climbs down off the boat. Looks up at Stephen.
Y'know, I told myself a million times  I didn't want to be a fireman. I  said bullshit to that line about  tradition and family legacy. I know  I split, and I know how you felt...
Yeah, you know. You know what it  felt like.
I gotta do this, Stephen. I gotta  know.
I think you're gonna find out, Brian.  Don't be late tomorrow.
A simple one-room walk-up. A stereo blares Chicago blues Brian buttons up his uniform in the mirror. He steps back looks at himself, -- and oh man what the hell am I doing.
Brian climbs into his car, turns the key -- nothing. He g out, looks under the hood, then SLAMS it down in frustrat

A pissed-off Chicago, hauling itself off to work in the  morning snap, passes by Brian's window. Tough Midwestern  brick. Tough Midwesterners. Heads-down in their 150 year with a wind committed to pushing the whole damn thing int Lake Michigan.
The train clacking away above him, Brian walks down the  sidewalk carrying his fire equipment. He turns a corner a comes on.

Brian stands there. It's his dad's station. Turn of the  century abused. Sooty with stone gargoyles and a pair of  faded red doors that suddenly CRANK OPEN as Brian comes u the drive. Fire engine 17 and ladder truck 46, lights  flashing, pull out onto the apron. The fireman sticking his head out of the passenger window Stephen. One look at the silver trumpet on his collar and know this isn't Fireman McCaffrey but Fire LT. McCaffrey.
You're too late, probie.
Tim, in ladder truck 46, waves a small bye-bye as both ri begin heading down the street.
(chasing) Goddamn it, Stephen...
Brian bolts full-out for the engine. At the last instant  before he falls on his face a fireman reaches out and dra him aboard.
It's Adcox, the fireman from the first scene, now a veter
Why baby McCaffrey, how ya doin'?
The Pumper driver, SCHMIDT, pops in a howling ROCK TUNE a they zoom off.
(re Brian to Adcox) You know this rug rat?
Know him? I practically raised him. (Jewish mom) And he never calls, he never writes...
Brian shouts over the noise to GRINDLE, 35, one more seat down.
I'm Brian.
I'm sorry.
Grindle sticks his nose out the window, sniffs, then begi buckling up his coat.
Boys, I do believe we have a  barbecue...
As Brian and Adcox fasten up their own equipment --
Smoke pours with confused indecision from every window of five story factory as the pumper and ladder company pull
(staring at confusing  smoke) I hate it when we gotta fucking go  look for it.
(to Schmidt) Call in another alarm. We're gonna  need some back-up.
Everyone begins strapping on air tanks and masks. Adcox d the rig's suction line to the hydrant. A beautiful illega parked Mercedes is blocking the way.
(to Stephen) Oh these moments do try me...
(admiring car) Be gentle.

Whistling to himself, Adcox SMASHES the brass coupling th the passenger window, runs the line through and SMASHES i out the other window before connecting up to the hydrant. Stephen and Grindle pull hose off the bed and move out.  Brian's so jacked up he can't get his air tank on right.  Schmidt calmly helps him into his gear.
It's only rock 'n roll, kid.
Stephen, Adcox and Grindle are crouched at the door, read to go. Brian takes a hose roll and runs to catch up when  he's cut-off by dazed Latin workers shouting incoherently him in SPANISH.
Hey, probie! How 'bout it, huh?
Brian pushes past the workers and takes his position on t hose line. Stephen reaches over and re-adjusts Brian's ai tank strap.
You're doing it wrong.
Stephen eases the door open. Thick smoke rolls sickly out over their heads.
(to Brian) Stay beside me.
And in they go...
Inside the smoke is like liquid lead. Going by feel, they hump the hose up one staircase after another, crawling on their hands and knees toward a dull red glow. Turning a  corner, they enter

Totally ablaze. Brian looks up in wonder at the buffeting waves of flame in the ceiling, at the SCREECHING timbers  crumbling to the white-hot floor. At the walls HOWLING in bestial agony. It is the most horrifying, and wonderful t he has ever seen.
Wash it to the windows?
No, we'll hit the son of a bitch  head on.
It's gonna flash, Stevie. We gotta  get behind it.
Nah, listen to it. It's a pussy.  It'll just steam on us. It won't  flash. Go high in the ceiling.

Adcox and Grindle shrug and pull their helmets down tight expecting the worst. Adcox opens up the nozzle, turning l a high pressure BLAST OF WATER into the ceiling. The fire SCREAMS in manic anger and HEAVES a cloud of HOWLING stea that WHIRLS back and BAKES them like lobsters. Brian gasp for air as swirling ash batters his facemask. A window  somewhere EXPLODES. Somebody shouts. Christ, you can't se anything. Stephen HOOPS in victory.
(to fire) I knew you were a pussy! C'mon! Steam  us! (to firemen) Let's go!

The chase is on! Going for the throat while the fire's  confused and defensive, the firemen SCRAMBLE through the  boiling cloud. They hit it in the ceiling, in the walls,  forcing it back and back. It HOWLS and CLAWS in anger,  furiously throwing cinders and broken timbers in their fa The walls ECHO with its SCREAMS as it retreats to a corne
Ya love it, probie?
I'm in heaven, Lt.
Hook us up to a stand-pipe.
Brian runs back to the wall to hook up his hose roll to t building water system. He goes to unscrew the cap with hi hydrant wrench but it keeps slipping off the nut.
Jesus, how 'bout man, huh? We're  gonna loose this!
Brian finally gets it hooked up and runs back.
Tim and three guys from his ladder company, come up an  extended aerial ladder, CRASH through a window and

begin HACKING their way toward Brian's company as -- BOOM It's a sudden, shattering vibration that shakes the build to its foundations. Then, a sucking sound: RUSH-RUSH-RUSH Stephen speaks calmly into his radio handset.
Hey Otis, is it...?
(into radio) Yeah.
Goddamn it, where's our backup?  Where's the second-in companies?
Sorry, man. John Wayne time.
(to firemen) Dig in!
The firemen hesitate. PENGELLY, the Truck Company Lt., lo at Stephen with concern.
Dig in, goddamn it!

The crews immediately gather in the center of the floor.  They turn over tables, chairs, anything to form a barrier circling of the wagons. -- BOOM! rush-rush-rush -- BOOM!  Each louder than the last. Stephen and Brian are ducked b an overturned desk. Adcox and Krizminski clutch hoselines like frontiersmen's Winchesters.
You're gonna love this.

It's only the fire's ghost here, lazy and slow. Off the corridor are rooms full of commercial sewing mach Brian enters one and drops to his knees. -- And now he's bursting from the building onto a short f escape, shouting at the top of his lungs.

-- The thing that really makes me  angry is the way your union has --

McCaffrey first  gained prominence as the subject of  a 1972 Pulitzer Prize winning  photograph taken at the scene of his  father's death..."

-- That really was incredibly work  you did. You and your brother,  fighting fires together, helluva  image, isn't it? You must feel lucky  to be assigned under his command.

-- A man suddenly steps between them to pump Swayzak's ha Brian shakes his head and walks away. Swayzak shoots a  concerned glance at Jennifer. She catches up with him at buffet table.

So now you suddenly care about my  future?

Hey, sorry if I made you look bad in  front of your boss. But I'm not gonna  be a poster boy for him, I'm trying  to do something here. There's five  hundred smoke eaters in this room  that do that stuff for real every  day. Tell Swayzak to talk to one of  them.

Stephen smiles and pushes off the bar -- right for Helen she dances.

Jackson.

As Jennifer watches Brian lead Stephen out the door.
